title: Electronic filter topology
text:
Electronic filter <a href="Topology%20%28electronics%29">topology</a> defines <a href="electronic%20filter">electronic filter</a> circuits without taking note of the values of the components used but only the manner in which those components are connected.
<a href="Filter%20design">Filter design</a> characterises filter circuits primarily by their <a href="transfer%20function">transfer function</a> rather than their <a href="topology">topology</a>. Transfer functions may be <a href="Linear%20filter">linear</a> or <a href="Nonlinear%20filter">nonlinear</a>. Common types of linear filter transfer function are; <a href="high-pass%20filter">high-pass</a>, <a href="low-pass%20filter">low-pass</a>, <a href="band-pass%20filter">bandpass</a>, <a href="band-stop%20filter">band-reject or notch</a> and <a href="all-pass%20filter">all-pass</a>. Once the transfer function for a filter is chosen, the particular topology to implement such a <a href="prototype%20filter">prototype filter</a> can be selected so that, for example, one might choose to design a <a href="Butterworth%20filter">Butterworth filter</a> using the <a href="Sallen%26amp%3Bndash%3BKey%20topology">Sallen–Key topology</a>.
Filter topologies may be divided into <a href="Passivity%20%28engineering%29%23Passive%20filter">passive</a> and <a href="Active%20filter">active</a> types. Passive topologies are composed exclusively of <a href="Electronic%20component%23Passive%20components">passive components</a>: resistors, capacitors, and inductors. Active topologies also include <a href="Electronic%20component%23Active%20components">active components</a> (such as transistors, op amps, and other integrated circuits) that require power. Further, topologies may be implemented either in <a href="Unbalanced%20line">unbalanced</a> form or else in <a href="Balanced%20line">balanced</a> form when employed in <a href="balanced%20circuit">balanced circuit</a>s. Implementations such as <a href="electronic%20mixer">electronic mixer</a>s and <a href="stereo%20sound">stereo sound</a> may require arrays of identical circuits.
Passive topologies.
Passive filters have been <a href="Passive%20analogue%20filter%20development">long in development and use</a>. Most are built from simple <a href="two-port%20network">two-port network</a>s called "sections". There is no formal definition of a section except that it must have at least one series component and one shunt component. Sections are invariably connected in a <a href="Cascade%20connection">"cascade"</a> or <a href="Daisy%20chain%20%28electrical%20engineering%29">"daisy-chain"</a> topology, consisting of additional copies of the same section or of completely different sections. The rules of series and parallel <a href="Electrical%20impedance">impedance</a> would combine two sections consisting only of series components or shunt components into a single section.
Some passive filters, consisting of only one or two filter sections, are given special names including the L-section, T-section and Π-section, which are unbalanced filters, and the C-section, H-section and box-section, which are balanced. All are built upon a very simple "ladder" topology (see below). The chart at the bottom of the page shows these various topologies in terms of general <a href="constant%20k%20filter">constant k filter</a>s.
Filters designed using <a href="Network%20synthesis%20filters">network synthesis</a> usually repeat the simplest form of L-section topology though component values may change in each section. <a href="Composite%20image%20filters">Image designed filters</a>, on the other hand, keep the same basic component values from section to section though the topology may vary and tend to make use of more complex sections.
L-sections are never symmetrical but two L-sections back-to-back form a symmetrical topology and many other sections are symmetrical in form.
Ladder topologies.
Ladder topology, often called Cauer topology after <a href="Wilhelm%20Cauer">Wilhelm Cauer</a> (inventor of the <a href="elliptic%20filter">elliptic filter</a>), was in fact first used by <a href="George%20Ashley%20Campbell">George Campbell</a> (inventor of the <a href="constant%20k%20filter">constant k filter</a>). Campbell published in 1922 but had clearly been using the topology for some time before this. Cauer first picked up on ladders (published 1926) inspired by the work of Foster (1924). There are two forms of basic ladder topologies; unbalanced and balanced. Cauer topology is usually thought of as an unbalanced ladder topology.
A ladder network consists of cascaded asymmetrical L-sections (unbalanced) or C-sections (balanced). In <a href="Low-pass%20filter">low pass</a> form the topology would consist of series inductors and shunt capacitors. Other bandforms would have an equally simple topology <a href="prototype%20filter%23Bandform%20transformation">transformed</a> from the lowpass topology. The transformed network will have shunt admittances that are <a href="dual%20impedance">dual network</a>s of the series impedances if they were duals in the starting network - which is the case with series inductors and shunt capacitors.
Modified ladder topologies.
Image filter design commonly uses modifications of the basic ladder topology. These topologies, invented by <a href="Otto%20Zobel">Otto Zobel</a>, have the same <a href="passband">passband</a>s as the ladder on which they are based but their transfer functions are modified to improve some parameter such as <a href="impedance%20matching">impedance matching</a>, <a href="stopband">stopband</a> rejection or passband-to-stopband transition steepness. Usually the design applies some transform to a simple ladder topology: the resulting topology is ladder-like but no longer obeys the rule that shunt admittances are the dual network of series impedances: it invariably becomes more complex with higher component count. Such topologies include;
The m-type (m-derived) filter is by far the most commonly used modified image ladder topology. There are two m-type topologies for each of the basic ladder topologies; the series-derived and shunt-derived topologies. These have identical transfer functions to each other but different image impedances. Where a filter is being designed with more than one passband, the m-type topology will result in a filter where each passband has an analogous frequency-domain response. It is possible to generalise the m-type topology for filters with more than one passband using parameters m1, m2, m3 etc., which are not equal to each other resulting in general mn-type filters which have bandforms that can differ in different parts of the frequency spectrum.
The mm'-type topology can be thought of as a double m-type design. Like the m-type it has the same bandform but offers further improved transfer characteristics. It is, however, a rarely used design due to increased component count and complexity as well as its normally requiring basic ladder and m-type sections in the same filter for impedance matching reasons. It is normally only found in a <a href="Composite%20image%20filter">composite filter</a>.
Bridged-T topologies.
Zobel constant resistance filters use a topology that is somewhat different from other filter types, distinguished by having a constant input resistance at all frequencies and in that they use resistive components in the design of their sections. The higher component and section count of these designs usually limits their use to equalisation applications. Topologies usually associated with constant resistance filters are the bridged-T and its variants, all described in the <a href="Zobel%20network">Zobel network</a> article;
The bridged-T topology is also used in sections intended to produce a signal delay but in this case no resistive components are used in the design.
Lattice topology.
Both the T-section (from ladder topology) and the bridge-T (from Zobel topology) can be transformed into a lattice topology filter section but in both cases this results in high component count and complexity. The most common application of lattice filters (X-sections) is in <a href="all-pass%20filter">all-pass filter</a>s used for <a href="Lattice%20phase%20equaliser">phase equalisation</a>.
Although T and bridged-T sections can always be transformed into X-sections the reverse is not always possible because of the possibility of negative values of inductance and capacitance arising in the transform.
Lattice topology is identical to the more familiar bridge topology, the difference being merely the drawn representation on the page rather than any real difference in topology, circuitry or function.
Active topologies.
Multiple feedback topology.
Multiple feedback topology is an electronic filter topology which is used to implement an <a href="electronic%20filter">electronic filter</a> by adding two poles to the <a href="transfer%20function">transfer function</a>. Biquad filter topology.
"For the digital implementation of a biquad filter, see <a href="Digital%20biquad%20filter">Digital biquad filter</a>."
A biquad filter is a type of <a href="linear%20filter">linear filter</a> that implements a <a href="transfer%20function">transfer function</a> that is the ratio of two <a href="quadratic%20function">quadratic function</a>s. The name "biquad" is short for "<a href="biquadratic">biquadratic</a>". Any second-order filter topology can be referred to as a "biquad", such as the MFB or Sallen-Key. However, there is also a specific "biquad" topology. It is also sometimes called the 'ring of 3' circuit.
Biquad filters are typically <a href="active%20filter">active</a> and implemented with a single-amplifier biquad (SAB) or two-integrator-loop topology. 
The SAB topology is sensitive to component choice and can be more difficult to adjust. Hence, usually the term biquad refers to the two-integrator-loop state variable filter topology.

Akerberg-Mossberg filter.
Figure 2 shows a variant of the Tow-Thomas topology, known as <a href="Akerberg-Mossberg%20topology">Akerberg-Mossberg topology</a>, that uses an actively compensated Miller integrator, which improves filter performance.
Sallen–Key topology.
The Sallen-Key design is a non-inverting second-order filter with the option of high Q and passband gain.
